case_name: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v. Ridmal Singh and Balji

facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 30 and 31 of 1963 are before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal Nos. 30 and 31 of 1963. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 31, 1962, of the Rajasthan High Court in D. B Civil Writ Petitions Nos. 376 and 377 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeals are by special leave from judgment and order dated August 31, 1962 of Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Civil Writ Petitions Nos. 376 and 377 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 31, 1962, of the Rajasthan High Court in D. B Civil Writ Petitions Nos. 376 and 377 of 1962. C. Setalvad, G. S. Pathak, N. P. Nathwani, H. J. Thacker and G. C. Mathur for the appellant  in C.A. No. 30 of 1963 .

facts.text: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar was elected to the House of the People at the third general elections held in February 1962 from Jhunjhunu Parliamentary Constituency in Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant before us, Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar was elected to the House of the People at the third general elections held in the month of February, 1962. He was elected from a companystituency known as the jhunjhunu Parliamentary Constituency in Rajasthan.

facts.text: Two election petitions were filed to set aside the election of Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar: one by Ridmal Singh (Election Petition No. 269 of 1962), an elector; another by Balji (No. 295 of 1962), an elector whose nomination paper was rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Two election petitions were filed for setting aside the election of the appellant. One of these was filed by one Ridmal Singh who stated that he was an elector in the said companystituency. Another application was filed by one Balji who was also an elector in the said Parliamentary Constituency and whose numberination paper was rejected by the returning officer.

facts.text: Election petitions have not yet been tried on merits.

anchor.surface_text: We are number companycerned in the present appeals with the grounds on which the two election petitions, one by Ridmal Singh and numbered as 269 of 1962 and the other by Balji and numbered as 295 of 1962, were based, because the election petitions have number yet been tried on merits

facts.text: Appellant filed two applications dated July 6, 1962 raising preliminary objections to maintainability of election petitions.

anchor.surface_text: By two applications dated July 6, 1962, the appellant who was one of the respondents to the two election petitions raised certain preliminary objections to the maintainability of the two election petitions.

facts.text: Election Tribunal dismissed preliminary objections by orders dated August 13, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal dealt with these preliminary objections by its orders dated August 13, 1962. It dismissed the preliminary objections.

facts.text: Appellant filed two writ petitions in Rajasthan High Court praying to quash orders dated August 13, 1962 and August 14, 1962 of Election Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant filed two writ petitions in the High Court of Rajasthan by which he prayed that the orders of the Election Tribunal dated August 13, 1962, and certain companysequential orders passed on August 14, 1962, be quashed and that an order or direction be issued to the Election Tribunal to dismiss the two election petitions

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court dismissed the two writ petitions by order dated August 31, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: These two writ petitions were dismissed by the High Court by its order dated August 31, 1962.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for special leave to this companyrt and having obtained such leave, has preferred the present appeals.

facts.text: Balji's nomination paper was rejected by the returning officer.

anchor.surface_text: Another application was filed by one Balji who was also an elector in the said Parliamentary Constituency and whose numberination paper was rejected by the returning officer.

facts.text: Returning officer rejected Balji's nomination paper by order dated January 22, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: a companyy of the order dated january 22, 1962, by which the returning officer rejected the numberination paper of the petitioner, signed or verified by the, petitioner.

facts.text: Ballu or Balji was not a contesting candidate within the meaning of s. 82 because his nomination paper was rejected. This is admitted.

anchor.surface_text: Now, it is admitted that Ballu or Balji was number a companytesting candidate within the meaning of s. 82 because his numberination paper had been rejected. The admitted position further is that all the companytesting candidates were joined to the petition as required by s. 82.

facts.text: All contesting candidates were joined as respondents in Election Petition No. 269 of 1962 as required by s. 82.

anchor.surface_text: The admitted position further is that all the companytesting candidates were joined to the petition as required by s. 82. Therefore, what happened was this All the parties whom it was necessary to join under the provisions of s. 82 were joined as respondents to the petition

facts.text: Election Petition No. 269 of 1962 impleaded Ballu or Balji as respondent No. 7 though not a contesting candidate.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the appellant is that Ballu or Balji whose numberination paper was rejected and who was number a companytesting candidate was improperly impleaded as respondent No. 7 to the election petition, though s. 82 requires that in cases where in addition to the relief o declaring the election of the returned candidate to be void

facts.text: Copy of Election Petition No. 269 served on appellant was not a true copy because not properly attested under signature of petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it is urged that there was number-compliance with the provisions of s. 81  3  of the Act because the companyy of the election petition served on the appellant was number a true companyy of the original filed before the Election Commission number war, it properly attested to be a true companyy under the signature of the petitioner who filed the election petition.

facts.text: Affidavit accompanying Election Petition No. 269 re corrupt practices was not properly made nor in prescribed form.

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, it is urged that there was number companypliance with the provisions of s. 83 of the Act inasmuch as the affidavit in respect of companyrupt practices which accompanied the election petition was neither properly made number in the prescribed form.

facts.text: Election Petition No. 295 of 1962 at presentation not accompanied by true copies as per s.81(3) due to enclosures not reproduced in served copy.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to Petition No. 295 of 1962 the grounds alleged are these Firstly, it is stated that at the time of its presentation to the Election Commission, the petition was number accompanied by true companyies of the petition as required by s. 81  3  of the Act because there was a reference to four enclosures at the foot of the schedule of the original petition, but in the companyy served on the appellant the enclosures were number reproduced.

facts.text: Election Petition No. 295 not duly verified as date and place of verification not stated.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly it is urged that the election petition was number duly verified inasmuch as the date and place of verification were number stated at the foot of the verification clause

facts.text: Copy served with Election Petition No. 295 lacked copy of treasury receipt for Rs. 2000 security deposit and properly signed copy of rejection order.

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, it is urged that a companyy of the treasury receipt showing the deposit of a sum of Rs. 2,000/- in favour of the Election Commission was number enclosed with the companyy of the petition which was served on the appellant, number was the companyy of the order dated january 22, 1962, by which the returning officer rejected the numberination paper of the petitioner, signed or verified by the, petitioner.

facts.text: Petition accompanied by Rs. 2000 security deposit via treasury receipt.

anchor.surface_text: Original treasury receipt of Rs. 2,000/- as security deposit.

facts.text: Dr. Z. A. Ahmed intervened in the appeals with petition dated April 4, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: In companyclusion we have to point out that we allowed one Dr. Z. A. Ahmed to intervene in these appeals on the grounds mentioned in his petition dated April 4, 1963.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds no merit in the two appeals.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we see numbermerit in these two appeals.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on May 7, 1963 by K. DAS J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. May 7. The judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS J.-These two appeals have been heard together as they raise some companymon questions of law and fact, and this judgment will govern them both.

issues.text: does this amount to non-compliance with, or contravention of, the provisions of s. 82?

anchor.surface_text: The question before us is, does this amount to non-compliance with, or contravention of, the provisions of s. 82? Learned counsel for the appellant wishes us to read s. 82 as though it said that the persons named therein and no others shall be joined as respondents to the petition.

arguments.claim: Impleading Ballu or Balji as respondent No. 7, who was not a contesting candidate, contravenes the mandatory provisions of s. 82 of the Act, making Election Petition No. 269 not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellant is that Ballu or Balji whose nomination paper was rejected and who was not a contesting candidate was improperly impleaded as respondent No. 7 to the election petition, though s. 82 requires that in cases where in addition to the relief o declaring the election of the returned candidate to be void

arguments.court_reasoning: If all necessary parties have been joined, impleading an unnecessary party does not breach s. 82; no warrant to read 'and no others' into the section.

arguments.claim: s. 82 provisions are mandatory and non-compliance requires dismissal under s. 90(3); no application of CPC principles for misjoinder.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant has contended that the provisions of s. 82 of the Act are mandatory provisions and any failure to comply with those provisions is fatal in the sense that it is obligatory on the Tribunal to dismiss an election petition

arguments.court_reasoning: No non-compliance with s. 82 occurred; foundation of argument absent.

arguments.claim: True copy under s. 81(3) means substantially true, not absolutely exact; test is whether variation misleads ordinary person.

holdings.text: If all the necessary parties have been joined to the election petition, the circumstance that a person who is not a necessary party has also been impleaded does not amount to a breach of the provisions of s. 82

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that if all the necessary parties have been joined to the election petition, the circumstance that a person who is not a necessary party has also been impleaded does not amount to a breach of the provisions of s. 82

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.82 requires joining specified parties; no textual warrant to imply 'and no others'; all contesting candidates joined, extra party does not contravene.

holdings.text: The word 'copy' in sub-s. (3) of s. 81 does not mean an absolutely exact copy, but means that the copy shall be so true that nobody can by any possibility misunderstand it

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that the word copy in sub-s. (3) of s. 81 does not mean an absolutely exact copy, but means that the copy shall be so true

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dictionary definition (Stroud); analogy to English cases on writs and Bills of Sale where minor clerical errors not fatal if not misleading.

holdings.text: The defects complained of with regard to Election Petition No. 269 of 1962 were not such as to mislead the appellant therefore there was no failure to comply with the last part of sub-s. (3) of s. 81

anchor.surface_text: Applying that test we have come to the conclusion that the defects complained of with regard to Election Petition No. 269 of 1962 were not such as to mislead the appellant therefore there was nofailure to comply

holdings.reasoning_summary: Every page attested; no need for foot signature; para omission minor, full details in body; test of misleading ordinary person not met.

holdings.text: A defect in verification under cl. (c) of sub-s. (1) of s. 83 is not fatal to the maintainability of the petition as it can be cured under CPC principles applied via s.90(1)

anchor.surface_text: it is impossible to accept the contention that a defect in verification which is to be made in the manner laid down in the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, for the verification of pleadings as required by cl. c of sub-s. 1 of s. 83 is fatal

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.90(3) omits s.83 post-amendments; s.90(1) applies CPC; defects curable.

holdings.text: Sub-s. (3) of s.90 requires dismissal only for non-compliance with ss.81 or 82, not s.83

anchor.surface_text: Sub-s. 3 of s. 90 originally referred to three sections... amended... now only s.81, s.82... clear... impossible to accept... defect in verification... fatal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative history of amendments excludes s.83 from mandatory dismissal; specific consequence principle limits effect.

holdings.text: The affidavit in respect of corrupt practices was in prescribed form; defect due to inexperience of Oaths Commissioner not fatal

anchor.surface_text: The mistake of the Oaths Commissioner in verifying the affidavit cannot be a sufficient ground for dismissal of the petitioners petition summarily, as the provisions of s. 83 are not necessarily to be complied with

holdings.reasoning_summary: Verification carries intended sense; curable; s.83 not in s.90(3).

holdings.text: Defects in copy served for Election Petition No. 295 do not invalidate compliance with s.81(3)

anchor.surface_text: the defects pointed out on behalf of the appellant are not of such a character as to invalidate the copy which was served on the appellant in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Treasury mentioned in body; certified copies verified; no need for vakalatnama or extra endorsement; not misleading.

holdings.text: There is no merit in these two appeals

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we see no merit in these two appeals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All preliminary objections rejected; affirms lower courts.

anchor.surface_text: Jagan Nath v. Jaswant Singh 1 , where it was held that s. 82 of the Act as it then stood was not mandatory. S. 82 then provided as follows A petitioner shall join as respondents to his petition all the candidates who were duly nominated at the election other than himself if he was so nominated. Sub-s. 4 of s. 90 then provided that notwithstanding anything contained in s. 85, the tribunal may 1 1954 S.C.R. 892. dismiss an election petition which does not comply with the provisions of ss. 81, 83 or 117.

precedents.cited_proposition: s. 82 of the Act as it then stood was not mandatory
precedents.cited_holding: s. 82 of the Act as it then stood was not mandatory

anchor.surface_text: Jagan Nath v. Jaswant Singh 1 , is determinative of the problem before us. We need not however pursue this question any further, because we have held that in the present cases there was no contravention of the provisions of s. 82. We now go to the second point. But before we do so, it may perhaps be stated that certain defects in the verification of Election Petition No. 269 of 1962 have been brought to our notice,

precedents.cited_proposition: s. 82 of the Act as it then stood was not mandatory

precedents.citation: Sri Babu Ran v. Shrimati Prasanni 1

anchor.surface_text: Sri Babu Ran v. Shrimati Prasanni 1 , it is contended that the principle in such cases is that whenever the statute requires a particular act to be done in a particular manner and also lays down that failure to comply with the said requirement leads to a specific consequence, it would be difficult to accept the argument that the failure to comply with the said requirement should lead to any other consequence 1 1959 S.C.R. 1408.

precedents.case_name: Sri Babu Ran v Shrimati Prasanni
precedents.cited_proposition: whenever the statute requires a particular act to be done in a particular manner and also lays down that failure to comply with the said requirement leads to a specific consequence, it would be difficult to accept the argument that the failure to comply with the said requirement should lead to any other consequence

anchor.surface_text: Kamaraja Nadar v. Kunju Thevar 1 . We are of the view that the word copy in sub-s. 3 of s. 81 does not mean an absolutely exact copy, but means that the copy shall be so true that nobody can by any possibility misunderstand it see Strouds judicial Dictionary, third edition, volume 4, page 3098 . In this view of the matter it is unnecessary to go into the further question whether any part of sub-s. 3 of s. 81 is merely directory.

precedents.cited_proposition: the last part of sub-s. 3 dealing with a copy is merely directive

anchor.surface_text: Pocock v. Mason 2 where it was held that the omission of the words the and by in the copy of the writ of capias prescribed by the schedule 2 W. 4, c. 39 did not invalidate an arrest. The reason given was thus expressed To ascertain whether or not an unfaithful copy produces any alteration in the meaning 1 149 E.R. 1291. 2 150 E.R. 51 supposes an exertion of intellect which it may be inconvenient to require at the hands of those who serve the copy.

precedents.cited_proposition: omission of the words the and by in the copy of the writ of capias prescribed by the schedule 2 W. 4, c. 39 did not invalidate an arrest
precedents.cited_holding: omission of words in copy does not invalidate if no alteration in meaning

anchor.surface_text: Sutton v. Mary and Burgess the copy of the writ served on the defendant omitted the letter s in the word she It was held that the omission was immaterial as it could not mislead anybody. In Morris v. Smith 2 , there was a motion to set aside the service of the writ of summons for irregularity, on the ground that the defendant being an attorney,

precedents.cited_proposition: omission of the letter s in the word she in copy immaterial as could not mislead anybody

anchor.surface_text: Morris v. Smith 2 , there was a motion to set aside the service of the writ of summons for irregularity, on the ground that the defendant being an attorney, he was only described as of Paper Buildings in the Inner Temple, London and the addition of gentleman was not given. It was held that the form in the statute 2 Will 4, c. 39 s. I did not require the addition of the defendant to be inserted in the writ and it was sufficient to state his residence.

precedents.cited_proposition: omission of addition like gentleman in copy or description not fatal if sufficient

anchor.surface_text: Cooke Vaughan 2 , it was held that where a writ of capias described the defendant by the addition of gentleman, but that addition was omitted in the copy served, the copy was not a copy of the writ, in compliance with the stat. 2 Will. 4, c. 39, s. 4 On behalf of the respondents a number of decision under the Bills of Sale Act, 1878 and the Amendment Act, 1882 45 and 46 Vict. c. 43 were cited

precedents.cited_proposition: omission of addition gentleman in copy made it not a copy
precedents.cited_holding: omission of addition in copy invalidates

precedents.citation: In re Hewer Ex parte Kahen 4

anchor.surface_text: In re Hewer Ex parte Kahen 4 , it was held that a true copy of a bill of sale within the Bills of Sale Act, 1878 s. 10, sub-s. 2, must not necessarily be an exact copy so long as any errors or omissions in the copy file are merely clerical and of such a nature that no one would be thereby misled.

precedents.case_name: In re Hewer Ex parte Kahen
precedents.cited_proposition: a true copy of a bill of sale must not necessarily be an exact copy so long as errors or omissions are merely clerical and such that no one would be misled
precedents.cited_holding: clerical errors in copy ok if not misleading
